The [[funeral procession]] was held early September 1, with photographs of Ali both before he died and those of his dead body covering the coffin. It had already been delayed for some hours, as Ali's father was unwilling to sign the death certificate for release of his son's body, since the cause of death listed was stated to be "unknown." It is uncertain if the certificate was ever signed or if the body was just released.<ref name="NYT2">{{cite news |title=Large Protest in Bahrain After Boyâs Death |author=J. David Goodman |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/02/world/middleeast/02bahrain.html |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=September 1, 2011 |accessdate=September 3, 2011}}</ref>
â
Activists stated that thousands of people attended his funeral. Afterwards, the mourners began marching No security personnel were present at the protest and the protesters dispersed by the afternoon. However, extensive protests were held in the national capital of [[Manama]] that night as the protesters tried to take back control of the [[Pearl Roundabout]], which was the site of protests earlier in the year until a government crackdown and the destruction of the monument. The protesters destroyed roads , attacked innocent civilians and vandalised stores and houses and they through molotovs cocktails at expacts working in the country .
+
Activists stated that thousands of people attended his funeral. Afterwards, the mourners began marching in the streets of Sitra carrying pictures of Ali and chanting 'Down, down, [[Hamad ibn Isa Al Khalifa|Hamad]]!'". No security personnel were present at the protest and the protesters dispersed by the afternoon. However, extensive protests were held in the national capital of [[Manama]] that night as the protesters tried to take back control of the [[Pearl Roundabout]], which was the site of protests earlier in the year until a government crackdown and the destruction of the monument. Government forces used tear gas and blocked roads with buses to stop the protests.<ref name="NYT2"/>
